content: This document outlines the declaration required from JioPay merchants when the owner's name or business name is not explicitly mentioned on the Proof of Business (POB) document. This declaration is specifically for Sole Proprietor merchants onboarded through the DKYC channel. It clarifies the conditions under which this declaration is valid, including scenarios where the owner's name is absent from the POB, or the business name is missing, but the owner's name is present. It also specifies that the beneficiary name on the settlement bank account must match either the business's legal name or the individual owner's name as per the POB/declaration.

llm_info.heading: JioPay Merchant Declaration Requirements: Owner/Business Name Not on Proof of Business

content: The declaration is invalid if the owner's name is present on the Proof of Business but differs from the name on the Settlement Bank Account proof. The declaration must be signed and stamped by the owner, matching the signature on the submitted Proof of Identity (POI). This ensures consistency and verification of the merchant's identity and business ownership. This section highlights the critical matching requirements to ensure the declaration's validity and prevent potential discrepancies during the KYC process.

llm_info.heading: Invalid Declaration Scenarios and Matching Requirements

content: The declaration begins with a statement of affirmation by the merchant, including their full name and residential address as per their address proof. This establishes the identity of the declarant and provides a verifiable address for communication and legal purposes. This section sets the foundation for the declaration by clearly identifying the individual making the statement and providing their contact information.

They agree that Jio Payment Solutions Ltd (JPSL) can verify their personal account using methods outlined in the merchant terms and conditions. content: Jio Payment Solutions Ltd. (formerly Reliance Payment Solutions Ltd.) provides payment solutions. Contact information includes: Registered Address, Corporate Address, Phone number, Website, and Email. The document is the Grievance Redressal Policy, outlining procedures for handling customer complaints. The document covers the scope, objectives, design principles, and grievance handling processes. It also includes roles and responsibilities, policy review, reporting to the board, transparency, and regulatory references.

llm_info.heading: JioPay Contact Information and Overview

content: This policy addresses customer queries, complaints, and disputes to maintain trust in the digital payments ecosystem. Jio Payment Solutions Ltd. (JPSL) recognizes the importance of customer satisfaction and has adopted the RBI’s Charter of Customer Rights. This policy provides a framework for handling grievances related to products, services, and redressal actions. JPSL aims to provide quality customer service and a centralized grievance redressal system for fair and transparent resolution.

llm_info.heading: Introduction to the Grievance Redressal Policy

content: Merchant Partner is defined as a business entity that uses JioPay's payment services to accept digital payments. A Consumer is defined as a customer who holds a valid payment instrument and makes payments for goods or services from a Merchant Partner using the payment instrument via the Merchant Partner's platform.

llm_info.heading: Definitions: Merchant Partner and Consumer

content: This policy covers all payment-related products and services offered by JPSL to its system participants and clients in India. It addresses queries, requests, complaints, and feedback from both online and offline Merchant Partners and customers.

llm_info.heading: Scope of the Grievance Redressal Policy

content: The policy aims to facilitate fair and timely resolution of customer complaints, ensure unbiased treatment, provide transparent and expeditious resolution, and educate customers on escalation mechanisms. The goal is to achieve prompt and satisfactory redressal of grievances, disputes, and complaints.

llm_info.heading: Objectives of the Grievance Redressal Policy

content: The policy is based on principles of fairness, quality, consistency, ownership, transparency, awareness, a simplified process, and empowerment. These principles guide the handling of customer queries, requests, complaints, and feedback to ensure a positive customer experience.

llm_info.heading: Key Design Principles of the Grievance Redressal Policy

content: Customers can raise queries, requests, complaints, and feedback (QRCF) through various channels. An automated system provides a unique tracking number for electronic submissions. A dedicated help desk handles QRCFs. The timeframe for resolution is communicated. QRCFs are classified based on customer feedback. The system covers transaction lifecycle stages, dispute types, and escalation paths. Outcomes are binding, and customers can approach external bodies if unsatisfied.

llm_info.heading: Grievance Handling and Resolution Process: Registration and Tracking

content: Customers can raise grievances related to transactions, service fulfillment, or technology. Transaction-related issues include no debit to account, debit to account, and refund not received. Service fulfillment issues involve problems with services availed. Technology issues include system downtime or service unavailability. Customers should contact JPSL, the issuing bank, or the Merchant Partner depending on the issue.

llm_info.heading: Customer Complaint Resolution: Transaction, Service, and Technology Issues

content: Merchant Partners can raise complaints related to transactions or technology. Transaction-related issues include refunds, transaction failures, processing charges, settlement delays, and reconciliation problems. Technology-related issues include system downtime, portal issues, and chargeback/dispute issues.

llm_info.heading: Merchant Partner Complaint Resolution

content: Level 1: Complaints can be lodged at care@jiopay.in. Resolution is attempted within 10 working days. For card-not-present and UPI P2M transactions with debit but no confirmation, auto-reversal is processed within T+5 days. Compensation of ₹100 per day is paid for delays beyond T+5 days. Merchant Partners can lodge complaints at merchant.support@jiopay.in, with a 10-working-day resolution timeframe.

llm_info.heading: Customer Complaint Resolution TAT and Escalation Matrix

content: Level 2: If unresolved or unsatisfactory at Level 1, escalate to the Nodal Officer at nodal.officer@jiopay.in (response within 10 working days). Level 3: If unresolved or unsatisfactory at Level 2, escalate to the Principal Nodal Officer at nodal.principal@jiopay.in (response within 10 working days). Level 4: If unresolved within 30 days, contact the digital ombudsman via https://cms.rbi.org.in/.

llm_info.heading: Escalation Levels for Customer Complaints

content: Customers must report disputes/complaints through available channels within the specified timelines. They should provide supporting documents, cooperate in the resolution process, track the dispute status, and escalate unresolved complaints according to the escalation structure.

llm_info.heading: Roles and Responsibilities: Customer

content: Merchants must acknowledge receipt of the dispute, submit proof of transaction fulfillment, actively support the investigation, and comply with outcomes. If the resolution favors the customer, the merchant must initiate a refund within the stipulated SLA.

llm_info.heading: Roles and Responsibilities: Merchant

content: The Payment Aggregator (PA-PG) acts as the coordinating entity between the customer, merchant, and banks. They log and track complaints, ensure resolution within 10 working days, keep the customer informed, and act in the customer's interest if no merchant or bank response is received. They maintain records of disputes and resolutions for a minimum of 5 years.

llm_info.heading: Roles and Responsibilities: Payment Aggregator (PA-PG)

content: Banks/Payment Service Providers must verify transaction status or authorization logs upon request and share findings with the PA. They must support the PA in fund reversals/refunds as per the outcome of the dispute.

llm_info.heading: Roles and Responsibilities: Banks/Payment Service Providers

content: The grievance redressal policy is reviewed annually or when regulatory guidelines change. Revisions are approved by the Board. The Board receives a summary of complaints periodically (quarterly or half-yearly). An analysis of customer complaints, including types, geography, source, turnaround time, compensation, root cause analysis, and corrective actions, is presented to the Board quarterly.

llm_info.heading: Policy Review and Reporting to the Board

content: An up-to-date copy of the policy, the procedure for filing complaints, access to the escalation matrix, and contact details of the Nodal Officer, Principal Nodal Officer, and The Reserve Bank - Integrated Ombudsman are published on JPSL’s website.

llm_info.heading: Transparency and Disclosure

content: This section provides links to the RBI guidelines referenced in the policy. These include guidelines on the Regulation of Payment Aggregators and Payment Gateways and guidelines on Harmonisation of Turnaround Time (TAT) and customer compensation for failed transactions using authorized Payment Systems, and RBI guidelines on Integrated ombudsman Scheme.

llm_info.heading: Regulatory References

content: Merchant Partner is defined as a business entity that uses JioPay's payment services to accept digital payments. content: If a complaint isn't resolved within the specified time or the resolution is unsatisfactory at Level 1, customers can escalate to the Nodal Officer at nodal.officer@jiopay.in (10 working days response). Root cause analysis is performed. JPSL follows RBI guidelines on ‘Harmonisation of Turn Around Time (TAT) and customer compensation for failed transactions using authorized Payment Systems’ dated September 20, 2019.

It details the number of units, nominal value per unit, and total value. It also includes details of debentures, such as the class of debentures, outstanding amounts at the beginning and end of the year, and any increases or decreases during the year. Additionally, it covers other securities (other than shares and debentures), including their type, number, and value.

llm_info.heading: Debentures and Securities Information

content: This section presents the turnover and net worth of the company as defined in the Companies Act, 2013. It also details the shareholding pattern, distinguishing between promoters and public/other than promoters. For each category, it provides the number of shares and the percentage held. The categories include individuals, government entities, insurance companies, banks, financial institutions, foreign institutional investors, mutual funds, and body corporates.

llm_info.heading: Turnover, Net Worth, and Shareholding Pattern

content: This section provides the number of promoters, members (other than promoters), and debenture holders at the beginning and end of the year. It also includes details of the composition of the Board of Directors, including the number of executive and non-executive directors at the beginning and end of the year, and the percentage of shares held by directors. It also lists the number of directors and key managerial personnel at the financial year-end date.

llm_info.heading: Number of Shareholders and Director Details

content: This section provides details of directors and Key Managerial Personnel (KMP) as of the closure of the financial year, including their name, DIN/PAN, designation, and the number of equity shares held. It also includes the date of cessation, if applicable. Furthermore, it details any changes in directors and KMP during the year, including appointments, changes in designation, and cessations, along with the effective dates and nature of the change.

llm_info.heading: Director and Key Managerial Personnel Details

content: This section details the meetings held, including meetings of members, the Board of Directors, and committees of the Board. For each type of meeting, it provides the date of the meeting, the total number of members entitled to attend, attendance details (number and percentage), and the type of meeting. It also includes the attendance of directors at board and committee meetings, including the percentage of attendance and whether they attended the AGM.

llm_info.heading: Meetings of Members, Board, and Committees

content: This section provides details of the remuneration of directors and key managerial personnel. It includes the number of Managing Directors, Whole-time Directors, and/or Managers whose remuneration details are entered. It lists the name, designation, gross salary, commission, stock options/sweat equity, and other components of remuneration, along with the total amount. It also includes the remuneration details for CEO, CFO, Company Secretary, and other directors.

llm_info.heading: Remuneration of Directors and Key Managerial Personnel

content: This section addresses compliance and disclosure matters, including whether the company has made compliances and disclosures in respect of applicable provisions of the Companies Act, 2013. If not, it requires reasons/observations. It also covers details of penalties/punishments imposed on the company, directors, or officers, including the name of the company/individuals, the authority, the date of the order, the relevant Act and section, and details of the penalty/punishment and any appeal status. It also covers compounding of offences.

llm_info.heading: Compliance and Disclosure Matters, Penalties, and Punishments

content: This section addresses whether a complete list of shareholders and debenture holders has been enclosed as an attachment. It also includes information about the company secretary in whole-time practice certifying the annual return in Form MGT-8, including their name, membership number, and certificate of practice number. It includes the declaration by the director and the digital signature information. Finally, it lists the attachments included with the form.

llm_info.heading: Attachments and Certification

content: This document is the JPSL Merchant Application Form (Supplementary), version 5, dated April 2024. It's used for JioPay merchant applications. The registered address is 5th Floor, Court House, Mumbai. The communication address is DAKC Gate 4, Navi Mumbai. The form must be filled in English using BLOCK letters. All fields marked with an asterisk (*) are mandatory. This supplementary form is used in conjunction with an existing SMID (Merchant ID).

llm_info.heading: JioPay Merchant Application Form (Supplementary) Overview

content: The Business Details section requires information about the merchant's business. Fields include Business Legal Name, Business Display Name, Business PAN, Email ID (used for critical communication), Business Address (Address Line 1, Address Line 2, City/District, State/UT, Pincode), and GST Number.  If the information is the same as the existing SMID, the 'Same as existing SMID' option can be selected. The number of additional SMIDs being requested must also be specified.

llm_info.heading: Business Details Section of the Application Form

content: This section requires details of the authorized signatory and contact person. Fields include Contact Person Name, Contact Person Email ID (used for critical communication), Authorised Person Address (Address Line 1, Address Line 2, City/District, State/UT, Pincode), Authorised Person Name, Authorised Person Date of Birth, Authorised Person Mobile Number, and Contact Person Mobile Number.  The 'Same as existing SMID' option is available for fields where the information is identical.

llm_info.heading: Authorised Signatory & Contact Person Details

content: This section requires the merchant's settlement account details. Fields include Account No., IFSC, Beneficiary Name, Bank Name, and Branch.  The 'Same as existing SMID' option is available if the settlement account details are the same as those associated with the existing SMID. All fields in this section are mandatory.

llm_info.heading: Settlement Account Details

content: The merchant must confirm that the provided information is true and correct. JPSL (Jio Payments Solutions Limited) can take action if any information is found inconsistent. Additional SMIDs are requested based on business requirements and documents submitted for the existing SMID. The merchant agrees to inform JPSL of any changes in additional SMID information and to comply with the existing Policies/T&C.

llm_info.heading: Merchant Declaration

content: This section outlines the requirements for additional SMIDs. Additional SMIDs are created based on documents submitted with the existing SMID application. If there are changes in the information related to the additional SMID, supporting documents will be collected as per policy.  Permission and Flags which need to be enabled will be submitted for each additional online SMID as per Annexure to JPSL Merchant Application Form. Supporting documents are required for fields marked with '*' if information changes.

llm_info.heading: Sign Up Personnel Details and Supporting Documents

content: This document is the Jio Payment Solutions Limited (JPSL) Merchant Application Form (MAF). It's used to onboard merchants for JioPay services. The form requires information about the merchant's business, authorized signatories, and payment preferences. Fields marked with an asterisk (*) are mandatory. The form includes sections for business details, payment modes, MDR & applicable fees, merchant declarations, and terms and conditions (Annexure A). Annexures B, C, and D are for internal JPSL use and list configuration options and supported payment methods.

llm_info.heading: Merchant Application Form Overview

content: The MAF requires merchants to provide their business's legal name, display name, PAN, GST number, CIN number, and contact details for the business contact person, including name, mobile number, and email ID. The mobile number is used for MID creation and Merchant Portal login, while the email ID is used for critical communication. Merchants must also specify their business address, entity type, and years in business. The form also captures the date of incorporation and the type of office premise.

llm_info.heading: Merchant Information and Contact Details

content: The MAF requires merchants to provide proof of identity and proof of address for the authorized signatory. Acceptable proof of identity documents include Aadhaar, Driving License, Voter ID, and Passport. Similarly, acceptable proof of address documents include Aadhaar, Driving License, Voter ID, and Passport. Merchants must also provide a photo of the authorized signatory. The form specifies the registered address and communication address of JPSL.

llm_info.heading: Proof of Identity and Address Requirements

content: Merchants must provide their settlement account details, including the account number, beneficiary name, IFSC code, bank name, and branch. The form also captures business details such as GST registration status (Registered or Unregistered, and GST Exempted), website, the type of business entity (Individual, Sole Proprietor, Partnership, etc.), the Merchant Category Code (MCC), the number of daily transactions, and the daily turnover.

llm_info.heading: Settlement Account Details and Business Details

content: The MAF lists various modes of payment supported by JioPay, including JioMoney/Jio Payments Bank, Netbanking, Wallets, PoS, Payment Gateway, Sodexo, Credit/Debit Cards, Prepaid Cards, UPI, BNPL, and Payment Link. Merchants need to specify the number of PoS devices they require. The form also includes options for EMI (tenure in months: 3, 6, 9, 12).

llm_info.heading: Payment Modes and Device Information

content: The MAF includes a section on Merchant Discount Rate (MDR) and applicable fees. It specifies different MDR rates for various transaction types, including debit cards (less than ₹2000 and more than ₹2000), credit cards (Visa/Mastercard, Amex/Diners), PoS device fees, UPI, EMI, prepaid cards, JioMoney, Wallets, NetBanking, and BNPL. The specific rates are detailed in the document.

llm_info.heading: MDR and Applicable Fees

content: The MAF includes a merchant declaration where the merchant confirms the accuracy of the provided information and agrees to the terms and conditions. It also includes a section for sign-up personnel details, including the employee ID, JPSL representative employee ID, name, agency name, and JPSL representative name. There is a declaration stating that merchant information and data have been verified with original KYC and business documents.

llm_info.heading: Merchant Declarations and Sign-Up Personnel Details

content: For online merchants, the form captures delivery period details (Aggregator/Merchant, Immediate/Deferred) and return policy information. Annexure A contains the Merchant Terms & Conditions. Key definitions include: Agreement, Acquiring Bank, Applicable Law, Consumer, EMI, Nodal Account, Merchant Partner Account, Merchant Partner Application Form (MAF), Merchant Partner Platform, Platform, Payment Mechanism, Payment Service Provider, Payment Bank, Payment Instruments, Point of Sale device (POS), Products, JPSL, JPSL Policies, Settlement Account, Transactions, and VoiceBox.

llm_info.heading: Online Merchant Information and Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Definitions

content: The agreement provides Payment Mechanism services on a non-exclusive basis. Merchants must inform JPSL within 30 days of any entity conversion. JPSL provides payment aggregation and facilitation services. Merchants must comply with all consumer orders and are solely responsible for product risks. JPSL can use merchant logos for marketing. Merchants must ensure security and encryption. Merchants must not store customer payment data, except for limited data for transaction tracking. JPSL can suspend payments if a breach is suspected.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Scope and Obligations

content: Merchants must comply with RBI regulations and applicable laws. They must use the Payment Mechanism for legitimate business only. Merchants are bound by the terms of the Acquiring Bank. Merchants must provide addresses of offices where the Payment Mechanism is used. Merchants must provide true and accurate documents. Merchants must not contest JPSL trademarks. Merchants must ensure fair acceptance of payment network cards. JPSL can share merchant information with group companies and affiliates for KYC and compliance.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Compliance and Restrictions

content: Merchants consent to JPSL sharing information with acquirers, POS distributors, payment networks, and other service providers. Merchants must provide information for the Payment Mechanism. JPSL can set off amounts from different merchant accounts for recovery. Information shared by JPSL is confidential. Merchants must not engage in prohibited businesses. Merchants must comply with payment network security requirements. JPSL facilitates Payment Services but is not responsible for third-party terms.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Data Sharing and Responsibilities

content: Commercial terms are between the merchant and consumer. JPSL is not responsible for non-performance or breaches. Merchants are liable for refunds and chargebacks. Merchants can share grievances with the nodal officer. JPSL is not responsible for EMI disputes. JPSL is not responsible for payment collection services unless received from the Payment Service Provider. UPI services are provided in association with the Payments Bank and are subject to NPCI and RBI guidelines.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Commercials, Refunds, and UPI

content: For merchants accepting Sodexo Meal Cards, JPSL is not responsible for transactions, settlements, or disputes. Merchants are solely liable for product delivery, quality, and refunds. Merchants must have an agreement with Sodexo. Sodexo is responsible for settling Meal Card transactions. Merchants must comply with all applicable laws related to Meal Cards and only sell meal products. JPSL is indemnified from any disputes related to Sodexo.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Sodexo Meal Card

content: Merchants confirm the accuracy of their bank account details. JPSL may verify account details by making a small transaction. Merchants authorize their bank to share account details with JPSL. UPI terms include providing correct details, transaction limits, and adherence to Payments Bank terms. JPSL and the Payments Bank can suspend UPI services for suspicious activity. JPSL is a facilitator and cannot control UPI transactions. Data sharing is subject to JPSL and Payments Bank policies.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Bank Account Verification and UPI Terms

content: JPSL, governing authorities, or Payment Service Providers may conduct audits. Merchants authorize JPSL to share information with credit rating agencies and regulators. JPSL's decision on account activation is final. Merchants are responsible for POS upkeep. The agreement's term is effective from the execution date and remains valid until terminated. JPSL's role is limited to facilitating the Payment Mechanism.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Inspection, Installation, and Term

content: JPSL's role is limited to facilitating the Payment Mechanism. The merchant has the right to accept or cancel a transaction. JPSL can restrict or prohibit transactions that violate laws or are suspicious. JPSL is not liable for merchant or consumer access issues. JPSL will notify merchants of planned maintenance. JPSL will notify specific technical and business procedures and policies to be followed for optimal use of the Payment Mechanism.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - JPSL's Role and Responsibilities

content: Merchants cannot act as payment intermediaries or resell the Payment Mechanism. Merchants cannot process cash advances. JPSL is not obligated to authorize or settle transactions that violate agreements or regulations. JPSL can share information with regulators if unauthorized, illegal, or criminal activity is suspected. Sharing information under these circumstances is not a breach of confidentiality.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Restricted and Unauthorized Use

content: Merchants pay fees as agreed in the MAF or other written documents. Fees are levied based on MDR. Changes in fees are communicated to the merchant. Continued use of services implies acceptance of fees. Payments are managed and processed to the merchant's settlement account from the Nodal Account. The payment schedule may be altered by JPSL. Merchants must report errors in settlements within 30 days.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Fees and Settlement

content: Merchants provide details of their bank account for settlement. JPSL may share settlement account details with Jio Payments Bank. If the Jio Payments Bank current account is used, the merchant authorizes the bank to share details with JPSL. Merchants cannot maintain more than ₹1 lac in the current account and must give instructions to transfer excess funds. Merchants are responsible for ensuring the account belongs to them.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Settlement Account Terms

content: JPSL can debit merchant accounts for excess settlements or recoveries. Refunds can be processed on merchant request, not exceeding the original transaction amount. JPSL will recover refund amounts from the merchant's settlement. If a consumer requests a refund, JPSL will request merchant confirmation. If a dispute arises, JPSL may withhold the transaction amount. Merchants must pay JPSL if there are insufficient funds for refunds.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Debits, Refunds, and Disputes

content: JPSL can withhold payments as detailed in the Grievance Redressal Policy. JPSL can withhold payments if a transaction is fraudulent. JPSL may defer payouts during investigations. Merchants will be given an opportunity to be heard. Disclosures and notices are provided electronically or on the Platform. Notices are considered received within 24 hours of posting or sending.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Right to Withhold Payment and Disclosures

content: Merchants must comply with payment industry standards and regulatory requirements. Merchants must follow reasonable security practices and PCI DSS recommendations. JPSL and regulatory bodies can audit merchant systems. Merchants must report security breaches within 2 hours. Merchants must not save customer card data. JPSL can conduct security audits.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Compliance with Payment Standards

content: Confidential Information includes data, technical, and business information. Merchants must keep Confidential Information confidential. Merchants must return Confidential Information upon demand or termination. Either party can terminate the agreement with 30 days' notice. JPSL can suspend or terminate the agreement without notice under specific conditions, including breach of terms, inactivity, or regulatory mandates.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Confidentiality and Suspension/Termination

content: Upon termination, the merchant account will be closed. Pending transactions will be canceled. Funds held by JPSL will be paid out, less fees and penalties. Merchants must stop using the Payment Mechanism. JPSL can delete merchant information. JPSL is not liable for termination or deletion. Merchants must provide records and return assets. JPSL will disconnect services.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Consequences of Termination

content: The relationship is contractual, not principal-agent. JPSL owns intellectual property rights. Merchants agree not to claim rights over JPSL's IP. Merchants indemnify JPSL against claims arising from breaches, violations of rights, or laws. Merchants represent and warrant that transactions are bona fide, accurately described, and compliant with laws. JPSL provides the Payment Mechanism on an 'as is' basis with no warranties.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Ownership, Indemnity, and Warranties

content: JPSL is not liable for losses from unauthorized access or use. In case of breach, the non-breaching party can recover actual damages. JPSL, its affiliates, and representatives are not liable for indirect, incidental, or consequential damages. JPSL's total liability is limited to ₹1000. Merchants must abide by RBI guidelines and the Anti-Money Laundering Act. Merchants represent that all representations are true and valid.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Limitation of Liability and Merchant's Terms

content: Data processing is subject to data privacy regulations. Merchants and JPSL must comply with the Information Technology Act, 2000. JPSL may collect, use, and disclose merchant and customer personal information. Merchants must obtain customer consent for data processing. The agreement is governed by Indian law, with Mumbai courts having exclusive jurisdiction. Disputes are settled through mutual discussion and arbitration.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Data Protection and Miscellaneous

content: JPSL can amend the terms and conditions by publishing them on the Platform. Continued use implies acceptance. JPSL can assign the agreement. Merchants can assign with 30 days' notice. The agreement does not limit JPSL's rights under other laws. Force majeure clauses apply. Either party can terminate the contract if force majeure prevents performance for more than two months.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Amendment, Assignment, and Force Majeure

content: The agreement constitutes the entire agreement. The parties are independent contractors. JPSL may amend the agreement at any time. The merchant must review the platform for changes. If the merchant does not accept changes, they must notify JPSL within 5 days. Severability clause: unenforceable terms are severed, and JPSL can substitute them. The merchant is bound by JPSL policies and terms and conditions.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Entire Agreement, Independence, and Severability

content: Merchants must use the VoiceBox at their premises and for the stated purposes. The VoiceBox and SIM card remain JPSL's property. Merchants must surrender the VoiceBox upon demand or termination. Merchants' details may be shared with telecom service providers. Merchants must not remove the SIM card. The warranty for the VoiceBox is 12 months, excluding the battery, charger, and USB cable, which have a 6-month warranty.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - VoiceBox Terms

content: Merchants are responsible for the safekeeping and maintenance of the VoiceBox. Merchants must not allow piracy or violate intellectual property rights. Merchants must not sell, assign, or modify the VoiceBox. Merchants must inform JPSL of loss or damage. Merchants are responsible for unauthorized use charges. Merchants must not use the SIM card for inappropriate purposes. Merchants must indemnify JPSL. Merchants are liable for VoiceBox fees.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - VoiceBox Responsibilities and Fees

content: Fees are subject to change. Failure to pay fees may result in late payment fees, penalties, and interest. JPSL may set off amounts, initiate legal proceedings, deactivate the VoiceBox, and/or blacklist the merchant. JPSL may repossess the VoiceBox if inactive for 3 months or if the monthly rental is not paid for 3 months.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - VoiceBox Fees and Consequences

content: JPSL classifies merchants as P2PM based on transaction value. If a P2PM merchant's transaction value increases, JPSL will notify them. JPSL may request additional KYC documents. If the P2PM merchant cannot provide the documents, JPSL can reject or hold transactions.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Low KYC/P2PM Merchant

content: The authorized person declares they are authorized to sign on behalf of the merchant. The merchant is authorized to undertake all activities. The provided documents are true and accurate. The merchant is responsible for renewals and further document submissions. The merchant assumes responsibility for consequences if information is insufficient, false, or misleading.

llm_info.heading: Annexure A: Merchant Terms & Conditions - Declaration

content: Annexure B is for internal JPSL use and lists configuration options. These include convenience fee settings, load money API, card vault/tokenization API, split settlement, configuration of other wallets, QR code service, S2S port opening, S2S URL configuration, PPI only (no load functionality), custom MDR configuration, convenience fee package, merchant logo on JioMoney page, offer flag, tokenization flag, subscription, EMI flag, collect link, and automated settlement file configuration.

llm_info.heading: Annexure B: For Office Use Only - Configuration Options

content: Annexure C allows for the addition of authorized signatories. It includes fields for name, pincode, mobile number, gender, address details, proof of identity, proof of address, date of birth, and PAN number. This section is repeated for up to four authorized signatories.

llm_info.heading: Annexure C: For Office Use Only - Additional Authorized Signatories

content: Annexure D lists supported payment methods, including Netbanking, Wallets, and Buy Now Pay Later (BNPL) options. It provides a comprehensive list of banks and processors for Netbanking, various wallet providers (Jio Money, Paytm, etc.), and BNPL providers (Simpl, ZestMoney, etc.) with their respective rates.

llm_info.heading: Annexure D: For Office Use Only - Supported Payment Methods

content: To onboard with JioPay, you'll need to provide KYC documents as proof of identity and address. For Sole Proprietorship merchants, the owner's documents are required. For Entity merchants (Partnership, Limited Company, Private Company, Trust, LLP, HUF), documents for all authorized signatories are needed. Acceptable documents include Aadhaar card (redacted), Passport, Driver's License (Maharashtra smart card only), and Voter's ID. These documents must show the name and photo (front) and address (back).

llm_info.heading: KYC Documents: Proof of Identity and Address for Sole Proprietorship and Authorized Signatories

content: Entity merchants must provide proof of business documents. Acceptable documents issued in the name of the Entity/Firm/Company include: FSSAI License, Shop & Establishment Certificate, GST Certificate, License from Drug Controller Authority, Certificate from Gram Panchayat/Block Development Authorities (with stamp), Registration/Trade License from Local/State/Central Govt., Registration/Trade License from Govt. Agency (SEBI, IRDA, ICAI, ICSI, ICWAI), Excise/Customs department registration, RTO Permit/Registration, VAT Certificate (for specific product types), Professional Tax registration, IEC, Trademark Registration, Factory Registration, SSI Certificate, Udyam Aadhar/URC, and Shop and Establishment Intimation receipt.

llm_info.heading: Proof of Business Documents for Entity Merchants

content: The following documents are NOT acceptable as proof of business: Weight & Measurement certificate.

llm_info.heading: Unacceptable Proof of Business Documents

content: To set up your JioPay account, you must provide documents for your settlement bank account. You need to provide one of the following: a cancelled cheque, a Bank Verification Letter (not older than 3 months for physical merchants), or a Passbook/Bank Statement (transaction entries not more than 3 months old, pre-printed details).

llm_info.heading: Settlement Bank Account Documents

content: For physical merchants, a passport-size photo of the shop owner/authorized signatory is mandatory for validation. Additionally, two clear photos of the shop are required (inside with stock and/or outside with display name). A live photo of the shop owner/authorized signatory is also mandatory, with a date and time stamp and LAT/LONG watermark as per product design.

llm_info.heading: Photo Requirements for Physical Merchants

content: Entity merchants must provide constitution documents based on their entity type. For Partnership firms, a Registered Partnership Deed is required. For Private/Public Limited Companies, the Memorandum of Association, Articles of Association (first and last 5 pages), Board of Resolution (signed by minimum 1 director/Company Secretary/MD), and Certificate of Incorporation are needed. For Trusts, a Trust Deed is required. For LLPs, a Certificate of Incorporation & Partnership Deed are needed. For HUFs, an HUF deed is required. Company PAN is also required.

llm_info.heading: Constitution Documents for Entity Merchants

content: Additional optional documents of business may be required. If the merchant is not registered with GST and has provided PAN or Form 60, this is noted. An Authorisation Letter is required if the entity/firm authorizes one or more persons as authorized signatories. This letter must be granted by the authorized partners/managing bodies.

llm_info.heading: Additional Optional Documents and Authorisation Letter

content: Financial documents are optional and can be provided. Acceptable documents include: Audited Balance Sheet of Last Financial Year, Last 3 (Three) months company Bank Account Statement, or Last 1 (One) Years GST Return / VAT / Income Tax Return.

llm_info.heading: Financial Documents (Optional)

content: Please note that the list of acceptable documents is dynamic and may change based on business requirements and compliance, legal, risk, and regulatory requirements.

llm_info.heading: Document Updates and Notes

content: To open a Jio Payments Bank savings account, you must be an eligible resident individual, as per Reserve Bank of India guidelines, and be 18 years or older. You agree to the terms and conditions at the time of account opening. You can open an account through the MyJio app (iOS App Store / Google Play Store) or in assisted mode via a Jio Payments Bank Banking Correspondent (BC) using the BC app.

llm_info.heading: Account Opening Eligibility and Process

content: Customers are permitted to open and operate only one savings account with Jio Payments Bank. Joint accounts are not offered. The maximum end-of-day balance allowed in a savings account is Rs 1.95 lakhs.

llm_info.heading: Account Operation and Limitations

content: You can open a Full KYC Account by providing PAN details, Aadhaar number (voluntary), Passport, Voter ID, Driving License, or NREGA card. You must complete the bank formalities, including biometric authentication at a Bank Correspondent (BC) outlet.

llm_info.heading: Full KYC Account Details

content: For Full KYC accounts (with Aadhaar and biometric authentication), the maximum credit balance at the end of the day is Rs 1.95 lakhs. There is no cap on the number or amount of transactions during the day.

llm_info.heading: Account Features and Transaction Limits (Full KYC)

content: You can access your savings account through the MyJio mobile app for digital transactions like fund transfers, bill payments, and recharges. These services are subject to change. Alternatively, you can use the BC app for cash withdrawals, deposits, fund transfers, bill payments, recharges, and upgrading to a Full KYC account.

llm_info.heading: Accessing Your Savings Account

content: The interest rate on savings accounts is subject to change at the bank's discretion and/or in accordance with RBI directives. The current rate will be displayed on the bank's website and mobile application. Interest is calculated daily and credited to the account quarterly.

llm_info.heading: Interest Rates and Calculation

content: Service charges are levied as per the bank's guidelines and policies, which are subject to change. The bank will provide 30 days' notice for any changes on its website, www.jiobank.in. Customers are responsible for staying updated on changes to the Terms, Most Important Terms, and charges by visiting the website.

llm_info.heading: Service Charges and Policy Updates

content: Customers can appoint a nominee for their savings bank account, subject to compliance with the bank's policy and formalities.

llm_info.heading: Nomination Facility

content: An account becomes dormant if it is not operated for two years or more. Deposits in accounts inactive for 10 years will be designated as unclaimed deposits and listed on the bank's website. These unclaimed deposits are subject to bank policy and RBI regulations.

llm_info.heading: Dormant and Unclaimed Accounts

content: You can close your savings bank account anytime by submitting a request through the MyJio app or at any BC outlet.

llm_info.heading: Account Closure

content: Customers can provide suggestions, feedback, or submit grievances through the MyJio app, banking outlets, by calling the Direct Helpline (1800 890 7070), or by writing to we.care@jiobank.in. You can also contact the District Grievance Redressal Officer (DGRO) linked to the BC for your district; details are available on the bank's website and at BC outlets.

llm_info.heading: Customer Grievance and Feedback

content: Deposits in savings accounts with Jio Payments Bank are insured up to a maximum of Rs 5,00,000 (Rs Five lakhs) for both principal and interest, as per the DICGC Act/Rules.

llm_info.heading: DICGC Insurance Coverage

content: The bank may disclose information about your savings account, including transactions, if required or permitted by law, rule, or regulation, or at the request of a public, legal, or regulatory authority. Disclosure may also occur to prevent fraud or in the public interest, without your specific consent.

llm_info.heading: Information Disclosure

content: These Most Important Terms & Conditions (MITC) form part of the Terms accepted when opening a savings account. In case of any inconsistency, the Terms will supersede these MITC.

llm_info.heading: Relationship between Terms and MITC

content: Reliance Payment Solutions Limited (RPSL) is a company committed to good governance. RPSL aims to have a Board of Directors with an appropriate composition, size, diversified expertise and experience and commitment to discharge their responsibilities and duties effectively. RPSL recognizes the importance of Independent Directors in achieving the effectiveness of the Board. The registered office is located at 5th Floor, Court House, Lokmanya Tilak Marg, Dhobi Talao, Mumbai - 400002, Maharashtra, India. The contact number is 022 – 3555 3800 and the website is www.jiopay.com.

llm_info.heading: Reliance Payment Solutions Limited (RPSL) Overview

content: This policy outlines the guiding principles for the Nomination and Remuneration Committee. The policy is for identifying qualified individuals to become Directors and to determine the independence of Directors, particularly for appointment as independent directors of the Company. This policy is crucial for ensuring effective board composition and governance within RPSL.

llm_info.heading: Policy Scope and Purpose

content: In this policy, 'Director' refers to a director appointed to the Board of a company. The 'Nomination and Remuneration Committee' is the committee constituted by RPSL’s Board in accordance with Section 178 of the Companies Act, 2013. An 'Independent Director' is defined as a director referred to in sub-section (6) of Section 149 of the Companies Act, 2013.

llm_info.heading: Definitions of Key Terms

content: The Nomination and Remuneration (NR) Committee and the Board review the required skills, knowledge, and experience for the Board and its members annually. The NR Committee considers factors like understanding of the Company’s business, professional ethics, and willingness to devote time. Proposed appointees must have a Director Identification Number, not be disqualified under the Companies Act, 2013, and provide written consent. They must also abide by the Company’s Code of Conduct and disclose interests.

llm_info.heading: Qualifications and Criteria for Directors

content: The NR Committee specifies the manner for evaluating the performance of the Board, its committees, and individual directors. The assessment can be carried out by the Board, the NR Committee, or an independent external agency. The NR Committee assesses the independence of Directors at the time of appointment/re-appointment, and the Board may assess the same annually. The criteria for independence are as per the Companies Act, 2013 and other relevant laws.

llm_info.heading: Performance Evaluation and Independence Assessment

content: Board members are expected to have adequate time and expertise to contribute to effective Board performance. Members should limit their directorships in other listed public limited companies to avoid interference with their role as directors of the Company. The NR Committee considers the time commitment of a Director's service on other Boards. A Director must comply with the limit of directorships as prescribed by the Companies Act, 2013 and other relevant laws.

llm_info.heading: Other Directorships and Committee Memberships

content: The Reserve Bank - Integrated Ombudsman Scheme, 2021, aims to resolve customer grievances against entities regulated by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) in a timely and cost-effective manner. This scheme operates under the Banking Regulation Act, 1949, the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934, the Payment and Settlement Systems Act, 2007, and the Credit Information Companies (Regulation) Act, 2005. The scheme applies to services provided by Regulated Entities to their customers in India. The RBI can suspend the scheme's operation if necessary.

llm_info.heading: Overview of the Reserve Bank - Integrated Ombudsman Scheme, 2021

content: Key definitions within the scheme include: 'Appellate Authority' (Executive Director in-Charge of the Department administering the Scheme), 'Complaint' (a written representation alleging deficiency in service), 'Deficiency in service' (a shortcoming in a financial service), 'Regulated Entity' (a bank, NBFC, System Participant, or Credit Information Company), and 'System Participant' (a participant in a payment system). Understanding these definitions is crucial for navigating the scheme and understanding the scope of its application.

llm_info.heading: Definitions within the Ombudsman Scheme

content: The Reserve Bank appoints Ombudsman and Deputy Ombudsman to carry out the scheme's functions. Appointments are for a maximum of three years. The RBI specifies the locations of the Ombudsman offices. To expedite complaint resolution, the Ombudsman may hold sittings at various locations. A Centralised Receipt and Processing Centre receives and processes complaints filed under the scheme, including online submissions via the portal (https://cms.rbi.org.in).

llm_info.heading: Appointment and Location of the Ombudsman Offices

content: The Ombudsman/Deputy Ombudsman considers customer complaints regarding service deficiencies. There is no limit on the dispute amount for which the Ombudsman can pass an Award. However, for consequential loss, the Ombudsman can provide compensation up to ₹20 lakh, plus up to ₹1 lakh for time, expenses, and harassment. The Deputy Ombudsman can close certain complaints. The Ombudsman reports annually to the Deputy Governor, RBI, and the RBI may publish the report.

llm_info.heading: Powers and Functions of the Ombudsman

content: Customers aggrieved by a Regulated Entity's act or omission resulting in service deficiency can file a complaint. Complaints can be filed personally or through an authorized representative. The complaint must be in writing or through other approved modes. The complaint process is designed to be accessible to customers seeking redressal for issues related to financial services.

llm_info.heading: Grounds for Filing a Complaint

content: A complaint is non-maintainable if it involves commercial judgment, disputes between vendors and Regulated Entities, grievances not directly addressed to the Ombudsman, general grievances against management, disputes under statutory orders, services outside RBI purview, disputes between Regulated Entities, employee-employer disputes, or disputes covered under the Credit Information Companies (Regulation) Act, 2005. Complaints must also meet specific conditions regarding prior communication with the Regulated Entity and time limits.

llm_info.heading: Grounds for Non-Maintainability of a Complaint

content: Complaints can be lodged online through the portal (https://cms.rbi.org.in) or submitted electronically or physically to the Centralised Receipt and Processing Centre. Physical complaints must be signed by the complainant or their authorized representative. The complaint must be in the format and contain the information specified by the Reserve Bank. This ensures a standardized and efficient complaint handling process.

llm_info.heading: Procedure for Filing a Complaint

content: Complaints offering suggestions or seeking guidance are not considered valid and are closed with communication to the complainant. Non-maintainable complaints are separated, and the complainant is informed. The remaining complaints are assigned to the Ombudsman's offices for examination, with intimation to the complainant. A copy of the complaint is sent to the Regulated Entity, requesting a written version.

llm_info.heading: Initial Scrutiny of Complaints

content: The Ombudsman can request information or documents from the Regulated Entity or any party involved in the dispute. Failure to comply without sufficient cause may lead to the Ombudsman inferring that the entity has no information. The Ombudsman maintains confidentiality of information, except as required by law or with consent. Information may be shared between parties to comply with natural justice principles.

llm_info.heading: Power to Call for Information

content: The Ombudsman/Deputy Ombudsman aims to settle complaints through agreement between the complainant and the Regulated Entity via facilitation, conciliation, or mediation. Proceedings are summary, and the Ombudsman can examine either party. The Regulated Entity must file a written version within 15 days. If the entity fails to respond, the Ombudsman may proceed ex-parte. The parties must cooperate in good faith.

llm_info.heading: Resolution of Complaints

content: The Ombudsman issues an Award if the complaint isn't resolved or if documents/information aren't furnished. The Award considers banking law, RBI guidelines, and other relevant factors. The Award may direct specific performance and compensation, up to ₹20 lakh for consequential loss, and up to ₹1 lakh for time, expenses, and harassment. The complainant must accept the Award within 30 days. The Regulated Entity must comply within 30 days.

llm_info.heading: Award by the Ombudsman

content: The Deputy Ombudsman or Ombudsman can reject a complaint if it's non-maintainable or offers suggestions. The Ombudsman can reject a complaint if there's no service deficiency, the compensation sought is beyond the Ombudsman's power, the complainant lacks diligence, the complaint lacks cause, requires elaborate evidence, or there's no financial loss.

llm_info.heading: Rejection of a Complaint

content: There is no appeal for an Award issued for non-furnishing of documents. The Regulated Entity can appeal an Award or complaint closure within 30 days. The complainant can also appeal an Award or complaint rejection within 30 days. The Appellate Authority can dismiss, allow, remand, modify, or pass other orders. The Appellate Authority's order has the same effect as the Ombudsman's Award or rejection.

llm_info.heading: Appeal before the Appellate Authority

content: Regulated Entities must facilitate the scheme's smooth conduct. They must appoint a Principal Nodal Officer (at least a General Manager or equivalent) responsible for representing the entity. They must prominently display the Principal Nodal Officer's contact details and the complaint lodging portal (https://cms.rbi.org.in) at branches. Salient features of the scheme must be displayed in English, Hindi, and regional languages.

llm_info.heading: Regulated Entity's Obligations: Display and Information

content: The Reserve Bank can make provisions to address difficulties in implementing the scheme. The Banking Ombudsman Scheme, 2006, the Ombudsman Scheme for NBFCs, 2018, and the Ombudsman Scheme for Digital Transactions, 2019, are repealed. Pending complaints and appeals are governed by the previous schemes' provisions.

llm_info.heading: Miscellaneous Provisions and Repeal of Existing Schemes

content: The document includes a detailed form for filing a complaint with the Ombudsman. The form requires information such as the complainant's name, address, contact details, details of the complaint against the Regulated Entity, nature of the relationship/account number, transaction details, and relief sought. It also includes declarations and authorization sections.

llm_info.heading: Form of Complaint (To be Lodged with the Ombudsman)

content: Reliance Payment Solutions Limited (RPSL) is a company registered in Mumbai, India. The registered office is located at 5th Floor, Court House, Lokmanya Tilak Marg, Dhobi Talao, Mumbai - 400002, Maharashtra, India. The company's contact number is 022 – 3555 3800, and the website is www.jiopay.com. This document outlines the Remuneration Policy for Directors, Key Managerial Personnel, and other employees of RPSL.

llm_info.heading: Company Information and Overview

content: RPSL's Remuneration Policy aims to align business objectives with individual performance. The policy's objectives include attracting, retaining, and motivating qualified directors; ensuring a clear link between remuneration and performance; and balancing fixed and incentive pay to reflect short and long-term performance goals. This policy is designed to support the successful operation and growth of the company.

llm_info.heading: Objectives of the Remuneration Policy

content: This policy provides guiding principles for the Nomination and Remuneration Committee (NRC) when recommending remuneration for Directors, Key Managerial Personnel, and other employees. The NRC is responsible for ensuring that the remuneration structure is fair, competitive, and aligned with the company's strategic goals. The policy helps the NRC in making informed decisions regarding compensation.

llm_info.heading: Scope and Purpose of the Remuneration Policy

content: A 'Director' is defined as a director appointed to the Board of a company. 'Key Managerial Personnel' (KMP) includes the Chief Executive Officer (CEO), Managing Director, or Manager; the Company Secretary; the Whole-time Director; the Chief Financial Officer (CFO); and any other officer prescribed under the Companies Act, 2013. Understanding these definitions is crucial for applying the policy.

llm_info.heading: Definitions: Directors and Key Managerial Personnel

content: The 'Nomination and Remuneration Committee' (NRC) refers to the committee established by RPSL's Board, in accordance with Section 178 of the Companies Act, 2013. The NRC is responsible for overseeing the remuneration policy and making recommendations to the Board regarding compensation for key personnel. The NRC ensures compliance with legal and regulatory requirements.

llm_info.heading: Definition: Nomination and Remuneration Committee

content: The Board, based on the NRC's recommendations, approves the remuneration for Executive Directors and Key Managerial Personnel, within shareholder-approved limits. The remuneration structure includes Basic Pay, Perquisites and Allowances, Stock Options, Commission (for Executive Directors), Retiral Benefits, and an Annual Performance Bonus. This structure aims to provide a comprehensive compensation package.

llm_info.heading: Remuneration for Executive Directors and Key Managerial Personnel

content: The Board, upon the NRC's recommendation, approves the remuneration for Non-Executive Directors, within the limits approved by shareholders. Non-Executive Directors may receive sitting fees for attending Board and committee meetings. They may also be entitled to profit-related commission, in addition to sitting fees. This structure compensates for their time and expertise.

llm_info.heading: Remuneration for Non-Executive Directors

content: Employee grades are assigned based on qualifications, work experience, competencies, roles, and responsibilities. Individual remuneration is determined within the appropriate grade, considering factors such as job profile, skill sets, seniority, experience, and prevailing market rates. This approach ensures fair and competitive compensation for all employees.

llm_info.heading: Remuneration for Other Employees

content: This document outlines the industries and/or product/service types that are restricted for JioPay merchant services. Merchants and/or industries listed here should not be solicited or onboarded. This list is not exhaustive but provides a comprehensive overview of prohibited business types. JioPay adheres to strict guidelines to ensure compliance and mitigate risk. The following sections detail specific categories of restricted merchants.

llm_info.heading: Overview of Restricted Merchant Services and Products

content: Merchants involved in adult digital content are restricted. Additionally, any merchant business model offering products/services solely based on guaranteed rebates, refunds, or prizes associated with the sale of those products/services is prohibited, especially if the rebate or refund equals or exceeds the product/service purchase price or value. This includes businesses that primarily rely on these incentives.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Adult Content and Rebate-Based Businesses

content: Any merchant engaged in any illegal activity is strictly prohibited. The sale of alcoholic beverages (beer, liquor, wine, champagne) is also restricted. Furthermore, merchants selling products or services promising future guaranteed results in general are not permitted. This includes businesses making unsubstantiated claims about outcomes.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Illegal Activities, Alcoholic Beverages, and Guaranteed Results

content: Merchants promoting hate, violence, or intolerance are restricted. Deceptive and unfair business practices are also prohibited. Collection agencies engaged in the collection of uncollectible debt, as defined by the relevant associations, are not permitted to use JioPay services. This ensures ethical business conduct.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Hate Speech, Unfair Practices, and Collection Agencies

content: Companies involved with chain letters of any type are restricted. Fortune tellers and astrologers are also prohibited. Additionally, companies involved with pyramid schemes are not allowed to use JioPay services. These restrictions aim to protect users from fraudulent activities.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Chain Letters, Fortune Tellers, and Pyramid Schemes

content: The sale of counterfeit goods is strictly prohibited. Merchants dealing in embargoed goods (as defined by the European Union) are also restricted. Furthermore, individuals and organizations associated with terrorism are not permitted to use JioPay services. These measures are in place to comply with international regulations and ensure security.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Counterfeit Goods, Embargoed Goods, and Terrorism

content: Travel merchants without a license from the National Travel Industry Bonding Organization are restricted. Trade in animals is also prohibited. The sale or exchange of E-Currency is not permitted. These restrictions are in place to manage risk and ensure compliance with industry standards.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Travel, Animals, and E-Currency

content: Bitcoin sales are restricted. Escort services are also prohibited. Extended warranty companies offering warranties beyond 1 year are not permitted. These restrictions are designed to mitigate risk and ensure compliance with financial regulations.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Bitcoin Sales, Escort Services, and Extended Warranties

content: Financial transactions, such as wire transfers, cash movement or transmitters, money orders, quasi-cash, and prepaid gift or credit cards are restricted. The sale of firearms, ammunition, or weapons is also prohibited. Get rich quick schemes are not permitted. These restrictions are in place to prevent fraud and ensure financial stability.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Financial Transactions, Firearms, and Get Rich Quick Schemes

content: Goods or materials that infringe intellectual property rights are restricted. Illegal drugs or paraphernalia are also prohibited. Investment programs or opportunities are not permitted. These restrictions are in place to protect intellectual property, comply with legal regulations, and prevent financial scams.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Intellectual Property Infringement, Illegal Drugs, and Investment Programs

content: Lifetime memberships with a membership fee exceeding €500.00 are restricted. Loan originators are also prohibited. Lotteries and raffles are not permitted. These restrictions are designed to protect consumers and ensure fair business practices.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Lifetime Memberships, Loan Originators, and Lotteries

content: Mortgage interest rate or payment reduction services are restricted. Money Service Businesses, including check cashiers, travelers checks, currency dealers & exchangers, are also prohibited. Offshore banking is not permitted. These restrictions are in place to comply with financial regulations and prevent money laundering.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Mortgage Services, Money Service Businesses, and Offshore Banking

content: Payment aggregators are restricted. The sale of real property (land, building, etc.) is also prohibited. Sports forecasting or odds making is prohibited if it involves gambling or wagering. These restrictions are in place to manage risk and ensure compliance with legal requirements.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Payment Aggregators, Real Property Sales, and Sports Forecasting

content: Football ticket sales for UK football matches need special approval due to legal restrictions. Timeshares are also restricted. Drugs (controlled substances) are prohibited. These restrictions are in place to comply with legal requirements and manage risk.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Football Tickets, Timeshares, and Controlled Substances

content: The sale of tobacco and cigarettes/vapes is restricted. Negative option subscriptions (auto-renew without notice) are also prohibited. Football tickets for Champion’s league, Europa league, World cup, and Supercup matches are restricted, as are Olympic games tickets. These restrictions are in place to comply with regulations and protect consumers.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Tobacco, Negative Option Subscriptions, and Event Tickets

content: Standalone solar panel businesses are restricted. Any services which involve an extended fulfillment period over 12 months are also prohibited. These restrictions are in place to manage risk and ensure compliance with industry standards.

llm_info.heading: Restricted Merchants: Solar Panel Businesses and Extended Fulfillment Services

content: While Mastercard’s full BRAM (Business Risk Assessment and Management) and GBPP (Global Brand Protection Program) list remains internal, JPSL (Jio Payments Solutions Limited) effectively mirrors these standards. This ensures transparency in JioPay's policy, which is available on its website. This alignment helps maintain industry best practices.

llm_info.heading: JioPay's Policy Alignment with Mastercard Standards

content: The Integrated Ombudsman Scheme 2021 streamlines the complaint resolution process for customers. This scheme eliminates the need for complainants to determine the specific scheme under which to file a complaint. It simplifies the process by consolidating various schemes into a single, unified system. This ensures that customers can easily lodge their grievances without needing to navigate complex jurisdictional boundaries.

llm_info.heading: Overview of the Integrated Ombudsman Scheme 2021

content: The Scheme defines 'deficiency in service' as the primary basis for filing a complaint, with a defined set of exclusions. This means complaints are less likely to be rejected simply because they don't fit a specific, pre-defined list of grounds. This broader definition allows for a wider range of customer issues to be addressed, ensuring a more inclusive and responsive complaint resolution process.

llm_info.heading: Definition of 'Deficiency in Service' and Complaint Grounds

content: The Integrated Ombudsman Scheme 2021 removes the jurisdictional boundaries previously associated with individual ombudsman offices. This centralization simplifies the complaint process, allowing customers to file complaints without concern for specific office jurisdictions. This change aims to create a more streamlined and accessible system for resolving customer disputes.

llm_info.heading: Elimination of Ombudsman Office Jurisdictions

content: A Centralized Receipt and Processing Centre (CRPC) has been established at the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) in Chandigarh. This center is responsible for receiving and initially processing physical and email complaints in any language. This centralized approach ensures efficient handling of complaints and provides a single point of contact for customers.

llm_info.heading: Centralized Complaint Processing Centre

content: The Principal Nodal Officer (PNO) is responsible for representing the Regulated Entity (RE) and providing information related to customer complaints. The PNO must be at least a General Manager in a Public Sector Bank or an equivalent position. This ensures a designated point of contact with sufficient authority to address customer concerns.

llm_info.heading: Role of the Principal Nodal Officer

content: The Regulated Entity (RE) does not have the right to appeal an Award issued by the ombudsman if the RE failed to provide satisfactory and timely information or documents. This provision emphasizes the importance of cooperation and transparency from the RE during the complaint resolution process. This aims to ensure accountability and efficient resolution.

llm_info.heading: Regulated Entity's Right to Appeal

3.22.1. As per the Applicable Law, the aggregate Customer balance across all deposit 
accounts including wallet, savings and/or current account, cannot exceed INR

sweep any excess amount, exceeding the prescribed threshold, into a savings 
account/Current Account maintained by the Customer at the Partner Bank. The 
Customer provides its consent for the Bank to enter into such an arrangement 
for sweeping its excess balance. 
3.22.2. The Bank shall collect explicit consent from the customer during or after

bank. If the customer does not provide explicit consent to the bank for the 
opening of Sweep Account with partner bank, the aggregate deposit balance of 
the customer with the bank will be restricted to INR 1,95,000. In such cases, 
where the customer has not provided the consent for enabling Sweep Account 
and the balance during the end of day reaches INR 1,95,000, JPBL reserves the 
right to reject the incoming credit transaction or park the excess amount in a 
designated account of the bank for which the customer will not be entitled to 
any interest.

Partner Bank current account and/or savings account ("Sweep Account") with

llm_info.heading: Fallback Chunk 1

content: JioPay Business offers digital payment acceptance solutions designed for businesses. It provides a safe, smart, and quick way to accept payments from customers. The platform supports various products, including Payment Gateway, Point of Sale (POS), UPI Hub, Biller Center, and a Business App. JioPay processes over 300 million transactions and supports 100+ payment methods. The platform is trusted by over 100K merchants and handles over 2 million API requests daily. This document provides an overview of JioPay's offerings and related information.

llm_info.heading: Introduction to JioPay Business

content: The Payment Gateway allows businesses to collect online payments directly on their custom websites or through tailored links and pages. It ensures safe and secure transactions, supports popular payment modes, and is optimized for both web and mobile platforms. Key benefits include increased conversion rates. For more detailed information, please refer to the product documentation or contact support.

llm_info.heading: JioPay Business Products: Payment Gateway

content: The Point of Sale (POS) solution is a smart terminal designed for accepting in-store payments. It supports multiple payment modes, including cards and UPI. Businesses can accept payments, generate UPI QR codes, design campaigns, and gain critical insights through the POS system. For more details, see the product documentation.

llm_info.heading: JioPay Business Products: Point of Sale (POS)

content: The UPI Hub is a comprehensive platform that enables businesses to collect payments using UPI. It allows for accepting payments and generating UPI QR codes. It also supports payment links. For more information on UPI Hub features and integration, please consult the documentation.

llm_info.heading: JioPay Business Products: UPI Hub

content: The Biller Center is a platform designed for accepting payments for recharges and bill payments of service providers. It allows businesses to collect payments, offers easy operations, and provides superior reach. It also supports sending payment links. For more details, please refer to the product documentation.

llm_info.heading: JioPay Business Products: Biller Center

content: The JioPay Business App offers simple, instant UPI payments. It allows for offline payments, auto reconciliation, and settlement. It also provides a 1 QR transaction summary. For more information on the app's features and usage, please consult the documentation.

llm_info.heading: JioPay Business Products: Business App

content: JioPay Business is built on technology to solve payment needs. It offers versatile features with regular launches, optimizations, and improvements. The platform is designed for security, reliability, and scale, reducing operational expenses. JioPay meets the highest compliance standards and offers robust integration with multiple institutions to ensure high success rates and uptime.

llm_info.heading: Why Choose JioPay Business?

content: Jio Payment Solutions Limited (formerly Reliance Payment Solutions Limited) is the legal entity behind JioPay Business. The registered address is 1st Floor, Building 4na, Maker Maxity, Bandra Kurla Complex Road, Bandra (East), Mumbai, Maharashtra, India, 400051. The corporate address is 2nd Floor B Wing, Building 25, Dhirubhai Ambani Knowledge City, Kopar Khairane, Navi Mumbai –400 710, India.

llm_info.heading: JioPay Business Contact Information

Also available are BillPay Terms & Conditions. These documents are essential for understanding the terms of service and compliance requirements. Please review these policies for detailed information.

llm_info.heading: JioPay Business - Legal and Policy Information

JioPay aims to revolutionize payments by providing quick and simple transactions without complex integration processes. The platform supports various payment methods, including cards, UPI, net banking, and wallets. JioPay products are tailored to meet the business needs of merchants in India.

content: Jio Payment Solutions Limited (JPSL) is committed to protecting user privacy. This Privacy Policy outlines how JPSL collects, uses, shares, and safeguards personal information. By using JioPay services, users consent to the processing of their personal information as described in the policy. Users should review the policy periodically for updates.

llm_info.heading: Privacy Policy: Preamble and Consent

content: This Privacy Policy applies to personal information collected directly from users and from JPSL's affiliates and third-party service providers. JPSL also receives personal information from various sources, including customer application forms and transactions.

llm_info.heading: Privacy Policy: Applicability and Information Sources

content: Personal Information includes data that can identify an individual, such as name, phone number, email address, address, date of birth, identification details, financial information, usage logs, and location data. It also includes device-specific information and sensitive personal information like passwords and biometric data.

llm_info.heading: Privacy Policy: Definition of Personal Information

content: JPSL uses personal information for identity verification, providing services, processing transactions, communicating with users, data analysis, improving user experience, marketing, and complying with legal and regulatory requirements. Information may also be shared with affiliates.

llm_info.heading: Privacy Policy: Use of Personal Information

content: JPSL will not disclose information for purposes other than those mentioned in the policy, except with user consent or as required by law. Information may be shared with business entities in case of mergers or acquisitions. JPSL engages vendors and affiliates for service provision, with strict security and confidentiality measures.

llm_info.heading: Privacy Policy: Disclosure of Personal Information

content: JPSL retains information as long as necessary for legal or business purposes. Security practices and standards are in place, with a comprehensive information security program. Access to personal information is restricted to a need-to-know basis. JPSL uses industry-standard security precautions to protect information.

llm_info.heading: Privacy Policy: Information Security and Storage

content: The JioPay platform may contain links to third-party websites, and JPSL is not responsible for their privacy practices. Users can modify or correct their information by contacting the grievance officer. Contact information for queries, concerns, and complaints is provided in the policy.

llm_info.heading: Privacy Policy: Third-Party Websites, Access, and Contact Information

content: For any queries, concerns, complaints, or feedback regarding the processing of personal information, users can contact JioPay at care@jiopay.in. This policy should be read in conjunction with the Terms & Conditions/agreement applicable for availing JioPay services.

Merchant Partner shall obtain necessary consent for this from the Consumers. Merchant Partner shall ensure adequate supervision for the performance of its obligations set out in this Agreement. The Merchant Partner agrees and understands that JPSL is providing UPI service in association with the Payments Bank in accordance with UPI guidelines, circular and/or regulations issued by National Payments Corporation of India (“NPCI”) and/or Reserve Bank of India (“RBI”) from time to time (“UPI Services”). The Merchant Partner agrees that JPSL or the payments Bank may at its sole discretion temporarily or permanently suspend Merchant Partners access to the UPI Services if JPSL or Payments Bank believes that there is suspicious or unusual activity being carried out through Merchant Partner’s UPI ID and UPI PIN. Also Merchant Partner agrees that JPSL or Payments Bank may reject UPI transaction for any reason including but not limited to risk management, fraud, suspicious transactions, unlawful transactions and/or violations of applicable law or JPSL Policies.
